Much of this is squandered, though, in a flat and conventional final act that turns Ned and Maria into the inventors of Method acting and, recoiling from its earlier subtlety, celebrates a world where men are men and women are women. SCOTT * 'TEAM AMERICA: WORLD POLICE' With the voices of Trey Parker and Matt Stone. Directed by Mr. Parker (R, 98 minutes). Without question the finest R-rated puppet action-musical of the past decade. Mr. Parker and Mr. Stone, the creators of ''South Park,'' apply their foulmouthed ingenuity to blow-'em-up cinema and current geopolitics. Saddam Hussein, a key character in the ''South Park'' movie, has been replaced by Kim Jong Il, a bespectacled blend of Eric Cartman and Professor Chaos, who plots to arm terrorists with weapons of mass destruction. If that doesn't sound like a laughing matter, fear not: there are plenty of profane, catchy songs and giddily offensive jokes to keep you amused. But like any good satire, this film has a distinct moral point of view. The members of Team America, the square-jawed action heroes who take on Kim and his supporting cast of left-wing Hollywood stooges, may blow up a lot of stuff, but they do it by accident, not by design. And while the movie is happy to mock American bluster, it also expresses a blunt, uncynical patriotism. SCOTT * 'VERA DRAKE' Starring Imelda Staunton and Phil Davis. Written and directed by Mike Leigh (R, 125 minutes). In this new film about a back-street abortionist, the moment invariably comes when the title character asks her client to bring her some boiling water. Vera's affect is so cozy, as nurturing as a maternal bosom, that it's always somewhat of a surprise when you remember that the water isn't for a warming cup of tea, but for the solution she dispenses. That's very much to Mr. Leigh's point since Vera wants nothing so much as to support the frightened, the dismayed and the impoverished who seek her help, who come to this tender dumpling of a woman because they believe they have no other choice. Here, the politics of abortion isn't a position that individuals can take and leave at will; it's what drives women underground to someone like Vera, with her clucks and smiles, her bar of lye soap and all that hot water. Set in London in 1950, and suffused with humanity rather than dogma, the film is easily Mr. Leigh's best work in a decade. DARGIS Rock/Pop A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy rock and pop concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. ERIC ANDERSEN, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Since the 1960's, Eric Andersen has been picking his guitar and singing about love in wistfully graceful songs like ''Thirsty Boots'' and ''Blue River.'' Lately, he's started to reflect about the passing decades and collaborate with songwriters like Lou Reed and John Prine. Tonight at 9:30; tickets are $20 and there is a $12 minimum. JON PARELES BACILOS, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. Bacilos, from Miami, draw their rock en español from across the Americas, switching gracefully and tunefully amid cumbia, salsa, bossa nova and pop ballads, and they have a Grammy Award (Best Latin Pop Album) and hit singles to show for it. Sunday night at 8; tickets are $30. PARELES BEASTIE BOYS/TALIB KWELI, Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., (631) 888-9000. The Beastie Boys are now old-school and proud of it, and their most recent album, ''To the Five Boroughs'' (Capitol), harks back to the electro blips of one of their early idols, Afrika Bambaata. Now that they're filled with good intentions, they're not as much fun as they were in their early days as uninhibited brats. Talib Kweli is an ambitious rapper who packs everything into his rhymes from politics to romance to anti-gangsta admonitions, all without forgetting to boast. Tonight at 7: tickets are $30.50 to $41. PARELES EARLIMART, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 653-1703. Earlimart has a streak of Neil Young folkiness, a streak of psychedelia and, on its latest album, an eerie echo of Elliott Smith, combined in ever-shifting proportions. Tonight at 9, with Midnight Movies, Silver Sun Pickups and the Love Story opening; admission is $8. PARELES FATBOY SLIM, Drive-In Studios, 443 West 18th Street, near Ninth Avenue, Chelsea, (212) 807-6795. Formerly a superstar D.J., now merely a star D.J., Fatboy Slim pursues his own gregarious vision of dance music: he likes big, memorable vocal samples; basslines so fat you can sing them, not just dance to them; exuberant beats that evoke the buoyant spirit (and sometimes sound) of pre-disco dance music. His new album, ''Palookaville'' (Astralwerks), is even more song-oriented than its predecessors -- it includes ''Put It Back Together,'' a lovely ballad sung by Damon Albarn of Blur. Unfortunately, the album is mainly filled with thin grooves and threadbare ideas. (The low point might be Bootsy Collins singing Steve Miller's ''The Joker.'') But this should be a good party regardless -- don't be surprised if Fatboy finds ways to bring many of these album tracks to life. Tomorrow night at 9:30 ; tickets are $40. KELEFA SANNEH * GIANT SAND/HANDSOME FAMILY, Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. Howe Gelb's songs for Giant Sand ponder big questions of mortality, love and fate in music with a skewed Southwestern spirit: sometimes quiet, sometimes twanging and lurching toward chaos. Brett and Rennie Sparks, who are husband and wife, write music and lyrics respectively for the Handsome Family. Their songs are part of alternative country's surreal and morbid wing. In stately melodies, often waltzes, Brett Sparks's serene baritone imparts tales of lost love and sentiments like, ''It's only human to want to kill a beautiful thing.'' Tonight, with Low Skies opening at 8:30; admission is $15. PARELES ROBYN HITCHCOCK, Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, at Sterling Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236; Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 653-1703. Tightly wound melodies and unsprung narratives meet in Robyn Hitchcock's songs, which bridge the psychedelia of Pink Floyd's Syd Barrett and the archetypal English ''nonsense'' of Edward Lear. Behind the whimsy is an acute observer of love, death and the entire evolutionary continuum from plants to bugs to humans. Onstage, Mr. Hitchcock free-associates stories that can be as improbably touching as his songs. At Southpaw, tomorrow night at 7, admission is $15. At Maxwell's, Sunday night at 9, with Shearwater opening; admission is $15. PARELES INTERNATIONAL POP OVERTHROW FESTIVAL, Arlene Grocery, 95 Stanton Street, Lower East Side, (212) 995-1652, and Acme Underground, 9 Great Jones Street, (212) 677-6924. Love songs driven by electric guitars were synonymous with Top 40 pop in the days of the Beatles, and still hanging on more self-consciously in the 1970's with groups like the Raspberries. But gradually, power pop became the province of collectors, revivalists and songwriters who couldn't wait to get their hearts broken so they could come up with another song. The International Pop Overthrow Festival in Los Angeles has rallied power-pop bands regularly for years, and it has spread to England and the East Coast. It continues tonight at 8 at Arlene Grocery, with the Grip Weeds (at 10:15) and other bands associated with the Rainbow Quartz label. Then it moves to Acme Underground for shows tomorrow and Sunday afternoons at 1 and evenings at 7, with bills of eight bands each (including a set Sunday afternoon at 3:30 by the tuneful and hard-nosed Marianne Pillburys) and it concludes at Acme on Monday night with another eight bands. Admission to each show is $10; the full lineup is at www.internationalpopoverthrow.com/eastc.html. PARELES J-LIVE, VAST AIRE, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. A hip-hop show starring a couple of local cult favorites. J-Live is a hardcore formalist, known for his rigorously constructed rhymes: in one of his tracks, ''One for the Griot,'' the rapper tells a story and then doubles back twice to provide alternative endings. He is to be joined by Vast Aire, from the duo Cannibal Ox, known for dense, murky, half-speed rhymes that you don't hear so much as absorb. Tomorrow night at 11, with MC Double AB; tickets are $12 in advance, $14 at the door SANNEH * KAYHAN KALHOR, Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Playing classical Persian music on the kemancheh, an upright fiddle, Kayhan Kalhor is a fiery improviser who moves from sighing, songful lines to fiercely percussive pizzicato fusillades and swirling arpeggios. Ali Akbar Moradi, who plays the tanbur (a three-stringed lute), shares the bill. Sunday night at 8; tickets are $28 and $35. PARELES MARCEL KHALIFE, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824 or (212) 545-7536. The oud player and singer Marcel Khalife, from Lebanon, moves easily between traditional Arabic music and his own settings of contemporary poems; he has written a concerto for oud and orchestra and dipped into jazz. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $25, $35 and $45. PARELES DAVID LINDLEY, Satalla, 37 West 26th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-1155. The guitarist David Lindley was once Jackson Browne's utility sideman. He went on to record albums of his own featuring his collection of cheap guitars, and has traveled the world soaking up string traditions, from Hawaii to Turkey, Ireland to Madagascar. Tonight at 8; admission is $23. PARELES LONG ISLAND REGGAE MUSIC FESTIVAL, Nassau Coliseum, 1255 Hempstead Turnpike, Uniondale, N.Y., (631) 888-9000. A lineup of longtime reggae stars includes Jimmy Cliff, Bunny Wailer, Maxi Priest, Luciano, Marcia Griffiths, Judy Mowatt, Sly and Robbie, Half Pint, Tony Rebel and others, covering the spectrum from lovers' croons to righteous resistance. Sunday night at 7; tickets are $45 to $85. PARELES * MUDVILLE, Pianos, 158 Ludlow Street, below Stanton Street, Lower East Side, (212) 505-3733. Mudville is a duo: Marilyn Carino sings about troubled longings and bleak surreal visions, while Ben Rubin surrounds her melancholy voice with brooding, minor-key tracks that start with electric piano and venture into smoky, ominous lounge territory, somewhere between Fiona Apple and Morcheeba. Tonight at 10:30, with Henry Shead at 9:30, Nikki Borodi at 8:30 and Jaymay and Ivan Sandomire at 7; admission is $8. PARELES NEVILLE BROTHERS, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. The Neville Brothers have been at the center of New Orleans funk since the 1950's. Art Neville, on keyboards, is a funk mastermind; Aaron Neville sings ballads with a voice of angelic purity and vulnerability. The Nevilles apply all their experience in syncopation to their own songs and, lately, cover songs like ''Ball of Confusion.'' Tomorrow night at 8; admission is $40. PARELES * OOIOO, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Yoshimi, the playful multi-instrumentalist who plays with the long-running Japanese free-rock group the Boredoms, also leads OOIOO, an all-female quartet known for shape-shifting, semi-improvised compositions that often sound both rigorous and delicate. The most recent OOIOO album is ''Kila Kila Kila'' (Thrill Jockey), a confounding but warmly enveloping disc that shows the group to be a (welcome) new sort of jam band, one content to concentrate on a single musical texture for minutes at a time, then suddenly switch directions with a series of woozy jump cuts. Tonight at 11, with Sonic Youth's Kim Gordon, who is to be accompanied by Ikue Mori and Jim O'Rourke; tickets are $14. SANNEH PROJECT OBJECT, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Frank Zappa's music was never easy to play. It called for players who loved both basic three-chord rock and all the whizzing, swerving, whimsical complexities that Zappa could devise. Musicians are still willing to devote themselves to its wayward intricacies, and Project Object has been working its way through the Zappa repertory for years. Its guests include past members of Mr. Zappa's bands: the guitarist Ike Willis and the singer Napoleon Murphy Brock. Sunday night at 8, tickets are $18 in advance, $22 Sunday. PARELES THE RADIATORS, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. The second-line backbeat of New Orleans funk is the heartbeat of the Radiators, a rock band that has been together since the 1970's. As band members sing about woman trouble and other frustrations, the groove keeps people shimmying. Tonight at 8; admission is $25. PARELES THE STRAWBS, Satalla, 37 West 26th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-1155. The Strawbs, led by David Cousins, were part of the 1970's wave of English traditional rock, setting their own takes on ancient legends to rich, modal melodies. They return minus the electric guitars. Tomorrow night at 8 and 10; tickets are $25 in advance, $30 tomorrow. PARELES * MATTHEW SWEET, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place at 15th Street, Union Square, (212) 777-6800. Power pop is a balance of yearning, melody and muscle, and Matthew Sweet likes his on the burly side. He shields his feelings behind noisy guitars, but he still reveals a tender heart. Tonight, doors open at 8 and Velvet Crush shares the bill; tickets are $25. PARELES DEREK TRUCKS, the Chance, 6 Crannel Street, Poughkeepsie, N.Y., (845) 471-1966 and Spirit, 530 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 268-9477. Joining a southern rock dynasty, the slide guitar player Derek Trucks splits his time between the Allman Brothers Band, which includes his uncle Butch Trucks on drums, and his own blues-rocking band, which constantly works the jam-band circuit. At the Chance tonight at 8:30; tickets are $20. At Spirit tomorrow night at 8:30; tickets are $25. PARELES * THE USED, Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. In 2002, the members of this Utah band put together a fragile, ferocious self-titled debut, full of hair-trigger love songs that kept devolving into screaming chaos. Now comes ''In Love and Death'' (Reprise), an impressive follow-up -- weird and catchy and unexpectedly funny. ''Listening'' wraps a frustrated anti-love song around a screamed, kindergartenish refrain: ''I'm not listening!'' And it ends with ''I'm a Fake,'' during which the singer, Bert McCracken, frantically shuttles between voices and attitudes. ''Look at me, look at me now,'' he pleads. Then the raw-throated rejoinder: ''I'm a fake! I'm a fake! I'm a fake!'' Tonight at 6:45; tickets are $22. SANNEH WU-TANG CLAN, Continental Airlines Arena, the Meadowlands, Route 120, East Rutherford, N.J., (201) 935-3900. A decade ago, Wu-Tang Clan was hip-hop's unstoppable vanguard alliance, encompassing brains, ferocity, comedy, romance, kung-fu trivia and all the ominous urban ambience that its producer and conceptualist, the RZA, could conjure. Uncounted solo albums later, the RZA, the GZA, Ghostface, Method Man, Raekown, Inspectah Deck, U-God, Masta Killa and Ol' Dirty Bastard have reunited. Their past live shows always verged on anarchy, and there's no reason to expect anything different now. Tonight at 8; tickets are $37.50 and $47.50. PARELES Jazz A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. MONTY ALEXANDER'S JAZZ PARTY, Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Columbus Circle, Broadway at 60th Street, Manhattan, (212) 258-9800. Mr. Alexander, a jazz pianist originally from Jamaica, has often refitted reggae songs and steel-drum sounds for a jazz-trio context; it's breezy, amiable stuff, and he can summon good swing. His band for this weekend includes the remarkable drummer Herlin Riley, and Clark Terry, a trumpeter and fluegelhornist who is one of jazz's great soloists. Sets through Sunday are at 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11 o'clock set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $30, with a $10 minimum at the tables and $5 at the bar. BEN RATLIFF GATO BARBIERI, Iridium, 1650 Broadway at 51st Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. All gatos have a few lives, and Mr. Barbieri, the saxophonist, has had three: first as a free-jazz wailer in the early 1970's, then as the soloist on the celebrated ''Last Tango in Paris'' soundtrack and now as a smooth-jazz balladeer. Sets tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and 10, Sunday at 8:45 and 10 p.m.; covers charges, $32.50 tonight and Sunday, $35 tomorrow, with a $10 minimum all nights. RATLIFF * CHICK COREA ELEKTRIC BAND, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592. Here is jazz fusion, the real article. The overall sound may be dated, but Mr. Corea's Elektric Band -- which existed from the mid-80's to early 90's, and has recently been resurrected, in a different lineup -- can be fascinating to hear. In the amped-up clatter of 16th notes, there are differences among players. The saxophonist Eric Marienthal injects a kind of soul, in longer, more expressive notes. Mr. Corea generally changes his rhythmic orientation every couple of bars. And the guitarist Frank Gambale, the bassist Ric Fierabracci and the drummer Dave Weckl can play like stylish nail guns. Sets through Sunday night are at 8 and 10:30; cover charge is $45 and there is a $5 minimum. RATLIFF ELLERY ESKELIN-ANDREA PARKINS-JIM BLACK, 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 929-9883. The saxophonist's trio, with Andrea Parkins on accordion and samplers and Jim Black on drums, is now in its 10th year; it's a frisky group, fracturing Mr. Eskelin's blues-and-bop roots with jagged backdrops. Music begins Sunday night at 9:30; the cover charge is $10. RATLIFF BENNY GOLSON QUARTET, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, Manhattan, (212) 864-6662. Mr. Golson, in his mid-70's, is an unlikely jazz hero: upbeat, fascinated with technique, a nonpurist who has spent equal time among the different aesthetic dispositions of East and West Coast jazz, a tinkerer who has written soul-jazz standards like ''Killer Joe'' as well as his own classical music. Above all, he is a first-class saxophone improviser, a Philadelphia colleague of John Coltrane going back to the mid-1940's whose own notions of phrasing and harmony have been deeply influenced by his friend's. Sets are tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11; cover charge is $25. RATLIFF * 'JACK JOHNSON FESTIVAL,' Frederick P. Rose Hall, Broadway at 60th Street, Manhattan, (212) 721-6500. A new Ken Burns documentary produces a cross-marketed pileup of culture, and his latest, ''Unforgivable Blackness: The Rise and Fall of Jack Johnson,'' is no exception. The full biography that drives it, written by Geoffrey C. Ward, is already in bookstores; Mr. Burns's film will be shown on PBS in January; and Blue Note records will release Wynton Marsalis's soundtrack to the film on Nov. 30. This weekend at Rose Theater, Jazz at Lincoln Center puts on an evening that's half film, half music. First Mr. Burns previews sections of the film; then Mr. Marsalis and his septet play sections of the soundtrack. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $10 to $150. RATLIFF * JOE LOVANO NONET, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037. A sock-to-the-gut band, with room for fun. It spans the last 50 years of jazz, with new arrangements of bebop-era tunes, some Coltrane writ large and Mr. Lovano's playful, sometimes calculatedly abstract, up-to-date originals. There are great players here representing the bricks and mortar of New York's jazz-club scene, including the saxophonists Steve Slagle, Ralph Lalama and George Garzone, and the drummer Lewis Nash; they create a great ruckus and heft, and leave you feeling that jazz is doing all right, thanks very much. Sets through Sunday night are at 9 and 11; the cover charge is $30. RATLIFF * DJANGO REINHARDT FESTIVAL, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. An annual event, and a surprisingly potent one. Django Reinhardt's slashing swing rhythm and overpowering sense of romantic melody makes imitation a worthwhile goal. This year's supplicants to the altar include the French guitarists Dorado Schmitt and Mayo Hubert, as well as the Basily Gypsy Band, from the Netherlands, and two other Dutch musicians, the pianist Peter Beets and guitarist Martin Limberger. Sitting in as guests are Gil Goldstein, on accordion, tonight, and Dave Samuels on vibraphone on Sunday. Sets are tonight through Sunday night at 8 and 11; cover charge, $35 tonight and tomorrow night, $30 on Sunday, with a $10 minimum all nights. RATLIFF JALEEL SHAW QUINTET, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063. A young alto saxophonist who has proved himself around New York recently; his band now includes Robert Glasper, a pianist of great promise, the similarly impressive guitarist Lage Lund, and the drummer Greg Hutchinson. Sets are tomorrow at 9 and 10:30; admission is $15 per set, $10 for members. RATLIFF HENRY THREADGILL'S ZOOID, Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, Manhattan, (212) 594-7149. Mr. Threadgill's newest band plays pieces shorter than his works in recent years, and an oud changes the texture; otherwise, Zooid is a refinement of the sweet-and-sour, jazz-tango-Balkan-funk matrix (always with a tuba) that Mr. Threadgill, one of our great composers, refined through the 90's. Tonight at 8; tickets are $20. RATLIFF THREE GUITARS: LARRY CORYELL, JOHN ABERCROMBIE, BADI ASSAD, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. It's Larry Coryell and John Abercrombie -- not unlikely colleagues -- as well as the Brazilian guitarist and singer Badi Assad; together they play sets that flicker between classical music, relaxed jazz and Brazilian song. Sets tonight through Sunday night are at 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $30 tonight and tomorrow, $25 on Sunday. RATLIFF MICHAEL WEISS TRIO, Fat Cat, 75 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 675-6056. Michael Weiss, a longtime member of the saxophonist Johnny Griffin's band as well as a leader in his own right, has the charging rhythms of bebop playing under his fingers, and he can focus the intensity in a tune as well as any pianist in the jazz mainstream. Sets tonight and tomorrow are at 10:30, midnight, 1:30 and 2:30; the cover charge is $10. RATLIFF Cabaret A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show. Full reviews of recent cabaret shows: nytimes.com/music. KLEA BLACKHURST, Opia, 130 East 57th Street, (212) 688-3939. ''For me, all musical comedy roads lead to Ethel Merman,'' declares Klea Blackhurst late in her show, ''Autumn in New York: Vernon Duke's Broadway.'' This singer from Salt Lake City makes good on that comparison the moment she opens her mouth and unleashes a bright, brassy rallying cry that is the vocal equivalent of strong home-brewed coffee without sugar or cream. She delivers an upbeat musical biography of the composer of ''April in Paris,'' ''Autumn in New York'' and ''I Can't Get Started,'' buttressed by the light swing arrangements of the Pocket Change Trio (Michael Rice on piano, Ray Kilday on bass and David Strauss on guitar and banjo). Tonight and Sunday night at 7 and tomorrow night at 9. Cover: $30; $15 minimum. STEPHEN HOLDEN BARBARA CARROLL, Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 419-9331. The Lady of a Thousand Songs is back in the Oak Room for Sunday brunch and evening performances. This elegant, red-headed pianist and singer is a poised entertainer whose impeccable pianism belongs to the school of jazz that maintains a sense of classical decorum at the keyboard. Even when swinging out, she remains an impressionist with special affinities for Thelonious Monk and bossa nova. Vocally, she belongs to the conversational tradition of Mabel Mercer with a style that's blasé but never cold. Sunday at 2 and 8 p.m. Cover: $55 at 2, including brunch at noon; $80 at 8, with dinner served at 6:30. HOLDEN BOBBY SHORT, Cafe Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 570-7189. After announcing his semi-retirement last year from performing at the Cafe Carlyle, this legendary singer and pianist changed his mind and is back in action for another season. Mr. Short never fails to conjure ebullient party spirits and has impeccable taste in songs. Expect to hear at least one of his three signature songs, ''Guess Who's in Town?,'' ''Just One of Those Things'' and ''Romance in the Dark,'' along with something by one of the two Dukes (Ellington and Vernon). Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:45 and 10:45. Cover: $95. HOLDEN * PAULA WEST AND THE ERIC REED TRIO, Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 419-9331. This San Francisco jazz singer has always relished transgressing stylistic conventions. Her new show includes a folk-jazz-rap version of Bob Dylan's ''Subterranean Homesick Blues,'' which she turns into a slurred mouthful of pure jazz rhythm. Her mischievous streak also asserts itself in slyly updated versions of Cole Porter's ''At Long Last Love'' and ''Anything Goes,'' that mention phenomena like nonfat creamer, the Hilton sisters and reality television. Her thoughtful renditions of ''Stormy Weather'' and ''Black and Blue'' find her emerging as a heavyweight balladeer. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11:30. Cover: $50; $50 prix fixe dinner at the early shows, $20 minimum at the late shows. HOLDEN Classical A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera and classical music events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. * denotes a highly recommended event. Full reviews of recent classical music and opera performances: nytimes.com/music. Opera 'CARMEN' Over the years, Bizet's gritty opéra-comique has succumbed to edema, and Franco Zeffirelli's Metropolitan Opera production suffers especially from bloat and stiffness, dealing in archetypes rather than living, breathing figures. Some new singers have stepped into the lead roles of this revival, which appears tonight for the last time this season: Irina Mishura takes on Carmen; and Richard Leech sings Don José. Rounding out the cast are Hei-Kyung Hong, a lyrical Micaëla, and the worthy newcomer Ildar Abdrazakov as Escamillo. Paul Nadler conducts. Tonight at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Sold out, but returns may be available at the box office. ANNE MIDGETTE 'CAVALLERIA RUSTICANA' AND 'PAGLIACCI' Opera's favorite double bill has returned in the Metropolitan Opera's venerable productions of Mascagni's ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci.'' Go not for a famous cast but for Mascagni's lightning-bolt blood and guts and Leoncavallo's equally sinister exercise in revenge and murder. Dennis Russell Davies conducts both operas. Tomorrow night at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Remaining tickets: $215. BERNARD HOLLAND 'CINDERELLA' Opera meets Broadway in more ways than one at City Opera this week. The company is giving itself over entirely to 13 consecutive productions of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical (not, admittedly, one of the duo's greatest hits, but enjoyable nonetheless) with a starry cast of a decidedly nonoperatic bent. Sarah Uriarte Berry, who's done ''Beauty and the Beast'' on the Great White Way, takes the title role, but more than likely two other contenders will be duking out who's to steal the show: the cross-dressing John (Lypsinka) Epperson as the Stepmother and the great Eartha Kitt as the Fairy Godmother. Gerald Steichen conducts. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 1:30 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 1:30 and 5:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570. Remaining tickets: $27 to $105 tonight, $32 to $115 tomorrow and Sunday. MIDGETTE 'I VESPRI SICILIANI' The convoluted story and clunky libretto to Verdi's ''Vespri Siciliani'' has probably kept this mature and stirring opera from gaining repertory status. So it's good to have this neglected and important work back at the Met after 22 years, a revival of John Dexter's grimly abstract 1974 production. In the impassioned and stylish performance by the conductor Frédéric Chaslin and a strong cast, ''I Vespri Siciliani'' emerges as a musically distinguished opera that, with its French inflections, anticipates Verdi's noble masterpiece ''Don Carlos.'' Don't fret if the story, based on the 1282 uprising and massacre by the people of Palermo, Sicily, against their hated French occupiers, seems implausible. Just let yourself get swept away by the music and relish the work of the compelling soprano Sondra Radvanovsky, the husky-voiced (and husky-framed) tenor Francisco Casanova, the elegant baritone Leo Nucci and the stentorian bass Samuel Ramey. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Remaining tickets: $215. ANTHONY TOMMASINI Classical Music BARGEMUSIC One of the best places to hear chamber music in New York is a converted barge docked in Brooklyn right next to the Brooklyn Bridge. Founded in 1977 and still run by the grandmotherly violinist Olga Bloom, Bargemusic presents concerts in a wonderfully intimate wood-paneled room with thrilling views of lower Manhattan and excellent acoustics. Tonight the cellist Leonid Gorochov and the pianist Niklas Sivelov play works by Stravinsky, Schnittke, Haydn and the ever-popular ''Arpeggione'' Sonata by Schubert. Tomorrow evening and Sunday afternoon these two players will be joined by the violinist Mark Peskanov, who is also Bargemusic's adventurous artistic director, for a program of music by Beethoven for piano trio, including the deceptively noble but actually radical Trio in E-flat (Op. 70, No. 2). Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 4 p.m.; Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083. Tickets: $35, $25 for students. TOMMASINI BELCEA QUARTET This young string quartet, founded a decade ago in London, proved impressive in its New York debut as part of Carnegie Hall's Distinctive Debuts series in 2000. Now it expands on that success in a pair of concerts. Tomorrow night it plays one of the same works, Britten's Quartet No. 3; a different Haydn quartet; and Mendelssohn's Quartet No. 4. On Sunday it plays a shorter program: Wolf's ''Italian Serenade'' and Beethoven's Opus 132. Tomorrow night at 8, 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500; tickets $35. Sunday at 11 a.m., Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; tickets $20. JAMES R. OESTREICH CHAMPAGNE CLASSICAL CONCERTS In the 1920's, it was not unusual for swanky hotels or restaurants to present classical music concerts, often with several well-known performers each contributing short sets. The Rainbow Room is hoping to revive that quaint tradition, or at least, a hint of it, with a series of Sunday afternoon piano recitals by young, accomplished players. Each recital lasts about 75 minutes, with no intermission, and the somewhat hefty ticket price ($75) includes a drink before the performance and dessert after it. The musical fare is light (if sometimes virtuosic), in keeping with the setting and format. This week the soloist is Richard Dowling, who is devoting his program to ragtime works by Scott Joplin, Zez Confrey, Joseph F. Lamb and others. Gershwin favorites round out the recital. Sunday at 5, the Rainbow Room, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, 65th floor, (212) 632-5000. Tickets: $75. ALLAN KOZINN EARLY MUSIC NEW YORK Frederick Renz and his enterprising ensemble have become deft arrangers of thematic programs, although sometimes an asterisk or two is required to explain programmatic loopholes. This week's program is called ''Renaissance Women,'' which might lead a listener to expect a full program of works by the comparatively few female composers whose works have been discovered and identified. There is, after all, more than enough of it to sustain a full program. As it turns out, four women are represented, including the extraordinary Barbara Strozzi, and three composers who were also nuns, Lucretia Vizzana, Suor Maria Xaveria Perucona and Chiara Margarita Cozzolani. There is also, however, lots of music by men. In some cases, the work is about a woman, most notably the Virgin Mary, as in a Palestrina setting of Salve Regina and a pair of devotional motets by P. de la Farge and Laurus Pativinus Mantuae. Other works, including a group of chansons by Crecquillon, are based on secular texts written from a woman's perspective. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 280-0330. Tickets: $35. KOZINN PAUL GROVES. This Louisiana-born tenor is best known to New Yorkers for his regular work at the Metropolitan Opera since his 1992 debut. James Levine has taken a special interest in his career. When Mr. Groves made his 1996 New York recital debut in Lincoln Center's Art of the Song series, Mr. Levine was his accompanist. Mr. Groves will sing again in that series on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, a recital accompanied by the Bosnian-born pianist Pedja Muzijevic, and others. Their program offers works by Fauré, Liszt and Rachmaninoff. But of special interest will be Britten's seldom-heard and challenging Canticle III ''Still Falls the Rain -- the Raids, 1940, Night and Dawn,'' and also the composer's ''Winter Words,'' a moody and affecting song cycle that sets eight poems by Thomas Hardy. Sunday at 5 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $48. TOMMASINI JUILLIARD SCHOOL BAROQUE CONCERT Until recent years, this might have seemed an oxymoron. The once-staid Juilliard School was slow to come to terms with the early-music movement. But now it has a Baroque specialist, the harpsichordist Lionel Party, on its faculty, and it has taken to showing off its wares in this line. Here Mr. Party leads performances of Bach's Cantata No. 51, ''Jauchzet Gott in Allen Landen,'' Handel's ''Music for the Royal Fireworks'' and other pieces. Tonight at 8, Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 769-7406. Free, but tickets are required. OESTREICH * NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC You could say the Philharmonic is crossing the Finnish line. The wonderful soprano Karita Mattila is making her New York Philharmonic debut this week in a set of songs by one of today's best composers, Kaija Saariaho, written expressly for her. The fine young conductor Sakari Oramo will lead the orchestra for the second time. The program includes the New York premiere of Sibelius's tone poem ''The Bard.'' The only non-Finnish element on the program, in fact, is Tchaikovsky's ''Manfred'' Symphony. In short, there's nothing not to like; all indications point to a really worthwhile evening. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $25 to $90. MIDGETTE ORCHESTRA 2001 This chamber orchestra, directed by James Freeman, was founded in 1988 to perform contemporary music. It has built a strong following in Philadelphia, where it is based, and it visits New York periodically as well. Mr. Freeman and company will be here on Sunday to perform two song cycles by George Crumb, ''The River of Life'' and ''A Journey Beyond Time.'' Both composed in 2003, the cycles are the first two books in Mr. Crumb's four-volume ''American Songbook.'' These two volumes are based on spirituals (among them, ''Shall We Gather at the River,'' ''Deep River'' and ''Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child''), and they are to be sung here by the sopranos for whom they were written: Ann Crumb, the composer's daughter, will sing ''The River of Life,'' and Barbara Ann Martin, who has long been closely associated with Mr. Crumb's music, will sing ''A Journey Beyond Time.'' Sunday at 3 p.m., Miller Theater at Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights. (212) 854-7799. Tickets: $25 to $30. KOZINN POMERIUM This magnificent early-music choir, founded in 1972 and led by Alexander Blachly, consistently offers thoughtful and enlightening programs. Mr. Blachly is devoting the group's program this time to the music of Ockeghem, one of the great 15th-century Flemish composers, and a pivotal figure: he studied with Dufay and probably Binchois, and taught Josquin. The program includes three of Ockeghem's Masses, including his two best-known settings, the Missa L'Homme Armé and the Missa Prolationum. The Missa au Travail Suis, an Ave Maria setting and a lamentation on the death of Binchois round out the program. Tomorrow night at 7:30, the Great Hall at Cooper Union, Third Avenue at Seventh Street, East Village, (212) 279-4200. Tickets: $20; $15 for students and 62+. KOZINN TRIO MEDIAEVAL Iraq wasn't the only thing ''handed over'' last summer. What's more, the handover of hegemony between female vocal groups in the not always placid world of early music was orderly. Anonymous 4 disbanded after last season and a New York farewell appearance at Corpus Christi Church, where it had performed for years. Now the Oslo-based Trio Mediaeval, which made its New York debut last season, takes over in the church's invaluable series Music Before 1800, performing the 13th-century ''Messe de Tournai'' and other works. Sunday at 4 p.m., Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 666-9266. Tickets: $40 and $25; $35 and $20 for students and 62+. OESTREICH Dance A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. * denotes a highly recommended event. Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. IVY BALDWIN The wildly imaginative Ms. Baldwin, a product of the North Carolina School of the Arts and New York University's Tisch School, has conjured up a scarily nutty world in her new ''Now Leaving Vanderville.'' Citizens go to war only on Mondays. (Well, that doesn't sound too bad.) They also stuff ducks for a living, however, as they wait patiently to be annihilated every week. All this is set to a score of songs by Kurt Weill, performed live by Franz Nicolay and Carrie Lewis. Also on the program is ''la table,'' a duet for snobs. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Dixon Place, 258 Bowery, between Prince and Houston Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 219-0736 or www.dixonplace.org. Tickets: $10 and $15. JENNIFER DUNNING * BLAKTINO PERFORMANCE SERIES Things are getting complicated in the world of ethnic nomenclature. This series, for instance, celebrates art by black, Latino and ''Blatino'' artists in two programs by Bronx-based companies this weekend. Tonight, Kim Vasquez's Kush troupe will perform West Indian dance that ends with a drum-and-dance jam, followed by Pedro Raposo's all-female Caracol troupe, which performs Afro-Dominican dance. Tomorrow the Arthur Aviles Typical Theater will present an evening of new and recent modern-dance pieces, set to scores that include music by Tito Puente and Celia Cruz, created by Mr. Aviles, a Bill T. Jones alumnus whose choreographic voice is distinctively brash, sweet-tempered and thoughtful. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, BAAD! (the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance), 841 Barretto Street, Hunts Point, South Bronx, (718) 842-5223. Tickets: $15. DUNNING DELFOS DANZA CONTEMPORANEA A dance troupe from Mexico that takes its name from the Delphic oracle of Greece makes its New York debut in choreography that combines great physicality with sensual and poetic imagery. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: $34. JACK ANDERSON * CHARLES DENNIS: 'HOMECOMING' This documentary celebrates 20 years of dance and ultimate funk at P.S. 122, of which Mr. Dennis is a co-founder. His film focuses on 10 choreographers who created seminal work there, with music by John Zorn, photography by Dona Ann McAdams and commentary by critics and presenters who include Mark Russell, for many years the theater's director and animating spirit. Sunday at 2 p.m., P.S. 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, Lower East Side, (212) 477-5288. Tickets: $5. DUNNING 'FOREVER TANGO' Better than Viagra, and for all ages, too. Luis Bravo's ''Forever Tango'' features sultry and comical dancers and first-rate musicians in a show, extended through Nov. 28, that is both tacky and transcendent. Tonight (and Tuesdays and Thursdays) at 8; tomorrow (and Wednesdays) at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m., Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200. Tickets: $45 to $85. DUNNING RENNIE HARRIS'S LEGENDS OF HIP-HOP Rennie Harris has created a fast-paced journey through hip-hop history in which he honors the pioneers of hip-hop and presents a panorama of hip-hop styles, all in only 50 minutes. Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m., Sunday at 12 and 5 p.m., New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Theater District, (212) 239-6200. Tickets: $10 to $30. ANDERSON HOI POLLOI Sara Sweet Rabidoux, the company choreographer, describes her work as deliberately awkward and creepily dear, borrowing techniques from film and fiction writing that include internal dialogues and dream sequences. Joining this modern-dance troupe will be the singer Heloise and the Savoir Faire Dancers. ''Think Blondie meets Fraggle Rock,'' Ms. Rabidoux comments. Nice of her to warn us. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Joyce SoHo Theater, 155 Mercer Street, between Houston and Prince Streets, (212) 334-7479. Tickets: $10; $8 for students and 65+. DUNNING RISA JAROSLOW AND DANCERS In her ''Whole Sky,'' Risa Jaroslow combines her dancers with members of the community to affirm her fascination with the ways in which people can interact in society. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077. Tickets: $20. (Related review, Page 3.) ANDERSON BARBARA MAHLER AND MEG WOLFE Barbara Mahler's ''Fragments'' is based on solos for herself. But some of her movements also filter into the choreography performed by Amy Kail and Vicky Shick. In Meg Wolfe's ''Stormy Days With Josephine,'' past and present collide on a Los Angeles freeway. Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday nights at 8:30, Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue at 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194. Tickets: $15. ANDERSON 'NEW DANCES AT JUILLIARD EDITION 2004' This free program consists of dances by four choreographers -- Robert Battle, Janis Brenner, Ronald K. Brown and Susan Marshall -- each of whom worked with a single class of young Juilliard dancers. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 3 p.m., Juilliard Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 799-5000. DUNNING * STREB S.L.A.M. You could say Elizabeth Streb and her performers are sitting pretty, with their own 150-seat studio-theater in which to create new work and regularly present it. But no one sits for long at a Streb program. The dancers fly, dive and dangle in new and recent pieces. The audience can walk around, as at a fairground, with popcorn provided. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7; Sunday at 3 p.m., S.L.A.M. (Streb Lab for Action Mechanics), 51 North First Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 384-6481. Tickets: $15. DUNNING VENCL DANCE TRIO Susan Vencl performed with choreographers like Albert Reid and Elaine Shipman before embarking on her own career of making dances. She characterizes her style as making architectural use of repeated and interlocking patterns and developing from close attention to the musical scores, here by Iannis Xenakis, Morton Feldman and Toshio Hosokawa. Tonight at 9; tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m., Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street, West Village, (212) 924-0077. Tickets: $15. DUNNING Art A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show. Full reviews of recent museum and gallery shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums * 'THE ART OF ROMARE BEARDEN,' Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Jan. 9. It's a pity only that this retrospective is so big. Art like Bearden's -- mostly small, intense and intricate -- deserves close scrutiny. His genius, aside from his poetic knack for piecing scraps of photographs and other tiny tidbits together, was to see collage as an inherent social metaphor: that its essence was to turn nothings into something, making disparate elements cohere, a positivist enterprise. His collages celebrated black culture and personal history, combined African masks with ancient Greek art, Matisse with patchwork quilts. ''There are roads out of secret places within us along which we all must move as we go to touch others,'' Bearden said. And that's exactly where he takes us. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+. MICHAEL KIMMELMAN * 'THE AZTEC EMPIRE,' Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, through Feb. 13. When a big survey of Aztec art opened in London in 2002, everybody flipped out. It was one of the hottest ancient-art events since Tutankhamen. Now an expanded version of the London show is at the Guggenheim, and it's a stunner. Objects from pre-Aztec Mexico set the stage, but it is material from the bloody-minded, deity-besotted Aztec culture that fills the museum's darkened ramps. Set on jutting platforms and dark recesses are a skull-headed earth goddess in a skirt of writhing snakes, a warrior metamorphizing into a bird and a god of spring and fertility shedding his skin. The show may be a little too heavy on theater and too light on information, but it's totally mesmerizing. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $18; $15, students and 65+. HOLLAND COTTER * 'COMIC GROTESQUE: WIT AND MOCKERY IN GERMAN ART, 1870-1940,' Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200, through Feb. 14. The horrors of World War I are usually credited with triggering the dark, often scathing humor that was used to comment on and combat some very unfunny developments in Germany in the first four decades of the century. But the Neue Galerie's splendidly multimedia revisionist show takes a broader view. It identifies paintings by Arnold Böcklin from the 1870's as a point of origin and then sweeps forward in a selective yet encompassing manner, touching on painting, poetry, graphic design and popular entertainment. It shows the influences of the satiric illustrator Thomas Theodor Heine on the mordant anti-Nazi montages of John Heartfield, and places artists like Lionel Feininger and Alfred Kubin in context. It culminates in the films of the great Karl Valentin, the star of stage, screen and cabaret who was Germany's Charlie Chaplin. Hours: Saturdays through Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 65+, $7. ROBERTA SMITH 'GREAT EXPECTATIONS: JOHN SINGER SARGENT PAINTING CHILDREN,' Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, through Jan. 16. Primarily known for his dashing portraits of high-born ladies sumptuously decked out, Sargent painted other subjects, too, not least among them children. And in these portraits, mostly of upper-class offspring, to be sure, he tended to get more real. This show, presenting about 40 works on the subject, has large ambitions. A major one is exploring how Sargent's likenesses tied in with the changing notions of childhood that came into play at the end of the 19th century, when children began to be regarded as distinctive personalities in their own right. For the most part here, he seems to see his young subjects that way, rather than as the syrupy stereotypes portrayed by his Victorian and 18th-century predecessors. Said to be the first exhibition to bring together Sargent's influential portraits of children, the show, with its catalog, is a refreshing new take on this bravura brushmeister. Hours: Wednesdays to Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of every month). Admission: $8; students and 65+, $4. GRACE GLUECK 'ISAMU NOGUCHI: MASTER SCULPTOR,' Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Aveune, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Jan. 16. In this well-planned chronicle of Noguchi's lifelong engagement with three-dimensional form, the highlight is a stunning gallery devoted to his anthropomorphic sculptures from the 1940's -- bony-looking vertical articulations that are surreal abstractions of body traits and attitudes. Cut mostly from thin slabs of marble or wood, the cleverly joined parts are notched to fit into each other without benefit of glue, nails or other fixatives. They form a quintessentially Noguchi synthesis of the human and totemic. But the show highlights other important areas of his achievement, not least of them the products of his early days in Paris (1927-28) where he turned out a wonderful series of abstract drawings that integrate biomorphic and geometric shapes with line, signaling his embrace of modernist art. A small gallery displays the quirky abstract sculptures he called ''Lunars'' that, rigged out with light bulbs in odd places, made lamps of a fine, goofy sci-fi quality that must have seemed off the wall in 1943. The show does not neglect his monumental pieces, which are displayed in the last gallery. Overall, a well-planned presentation that moves engrossingly along. Hours and admission: see above. GLUECK * 'PRINCELY SPLENDOR: THE DRESDEN COURT, 1580-1620,' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 30. A densely baubled selection of some of the tools, armor, sculpture and bejeweled gewgaws that the princes of Dresden accumulated in the late 16th and early 17th centuries. Ignore the hackneyed and pompous exhibition title and consider this a constructive reminder of the artistic roots of wonderment. Besides ivory handled hammers, a 14-piece pocketknife, a mother-of-pearl cup in the shape of a parrot, silk doublets trimmed in silver and gold, a brass horn and several automatons, which move about on hidden mechanized wheels, there is a portable hunting and writing desk. It is neatly stocked with gardening tools, writing and painting implements, cupping glasses, an oil cruet, soap boxes, scales, strainers, funnels, vintner's tools, barber's instruments, farrier's tools, locksmith tools -- in sum, the world, as a mirror of divine reason, a cabinet of wonders, for princes who had everything. Hours: Sundays, Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7. KIMMELMAN 'GILBERT STUART,' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 16. Known today mostly for his multiple images of George Washington, 14 of which are shown here, Stuart (1755-1828) painted many other faces, famous and not, as seen in this full-blown retrospective. Among them were Thomas Jefferson; John and Abigail Adams; the fur magnate John Jacob Astor; John Jay, first chief justice of the United States; and doctors, lawyers, clergymen and countless British and American blueboods, their wives, children and dogs. Possessed of a penetrating talent augmented by a knowledge of physiognomy, Stuart apparently sussed out his subjects in lively conversation as he worked. ''The Skater (William Grant),'' done in 1782, is a stunning full-length figure of an acquaintance from Stuart's London days performing a graceful maneuver on the ice. It is, far and beyond being a portrait, a haunting work whose liberating air seems to extol the individual as master of his fate. The last Stuart retrospective was held nearly 40 years ago; this one reveals for a new generation that he was and remains one of our greatest American painters. Hours and admission: see above. GLUECK 'TOTEMS TO TURQUOISE: NATIVE NORTH AMERICAN JEWELRY ARTS OF THE NORTHWEST AND SOUTHWEST,' American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100, through July 10. Think of cave murals and Renaissance altarpieces used to contextualize examples of modern and contemporary painting and you've got the equivalent of this exhibition, a mixed bag of old and new, quality and special pleading. Here examples of jewelry and other small objects that date back to prehistoric times lend credence to late 20th and 21st century works that are sometimes little more than glitzy knockoffs. Enough recent efforts stand out to make the show a valuable essay on the very notion of traditions, how they are formed, perpetuated, renewed, exploited or exhausted. But claiming to follow the beliefs or crafts of one's ancestors does not guarantee a special purchase on spirituality. All art is essentially a faith-based initiative. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. Admission: $13; children, $7.50; students and 62+, $10. SMITH Galleries: Uptown 'BOB THE ROMAN: HEROIC ANTIQUITY AND THE ARCHITECTURE OF ROBERT ADAM,' Gallery of the New York School of Interior Design, 161 East 69th Street, (212) 472-1500, through Dec. 4. Not for nothing did the Scotsman Robert Adam (1728-1792) playfully restyle himself ''Bob the Roman'' after soaking up the Eternal City on his youthful grand tour of Europe. Nearly everything he turned his hand to later as the celebrated architect, designer and interior decorator of late 18th-century England evoked the classical spirit of his beloved Rome. This show of more than 80 drawings made in the Adam office (Robert's brother, James, was his partner) is an enlightening introduction to the Adam brothers' scope. The works range from a nine-foot-long view of the facade of an intricate fantasy palace to numerous plans and proposals for town houses, villas and castles, along with their ornamentation, many of which actually got built. GLUECK BRYAN HUNT: 'AIRSHIPS,' Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 744-7400, through Dec. 11. Mr. Hunt became known in the mid 70's for beautiful sculptures in the form of miniature dirigibles made with balsa wood interior framing and paper skins covered with metal leaf or paint. Eight of these works, ranging in length from 40 to 64 inches, are on view here. Attached to the wall at one end, they hover mysteriously overhead. KEN JOHNSON ALFRED LESLIE: 'EXPRESSING THE ZEITGEIST,' Allan Stone Gallery, 113 East 90th Street, (212) 987-4997, through Dec. 22. Although primarily thought of today as a realist painter, Alfred Leslie started out as a second-generation Abstract Expressionist, a mover and shaker of the downtown world whose studio was a center of happenings and other events besides painting. This presentation of his vibrant early work from 1951 to 1962 ranges from tiny collages to large canvases, whose colors, chosen from a broad palette, were energetically laid on with heavy, loaded brushstrokes exuberantly accompanied by drips and spatter. They characteristically carry a pair or two of painted bars that punctuate the highly textured, often collaged surfaces like exclamation points. GLUECK * 'NEUE SACHLICHKEIT: NEW OBJECTIVITY IN WEIMAR GERMANY,' Ubu Gallery, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444, through Dec. 18. Heralded by the Expressionist Ludwig Meidner as a ''fanatical, fervent naturalism,'' the ostensibly realist style known as Neue Sachlichkeit was all that and more, as this uneven 80-work show vigorously suggests. It features the majestically factual photographs of August Sander, Karl Blossfeldt and Albert Renger-Patzsch, and works based on photographs by Georg Scholz, Eddy Smith and George Grosz that bring out reality's grotesque side. Carl Grossberg's pared-down, jewel-colored portrayals of German factories and villages evoke American Precisionism. SMITH 'SO FAR SO CLOSE: CONTEMPORARY ART FROM GUADALAJARA,' The Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212) 277-8343, through Jan. 21. This five-artist exhibition is intended to show that Mexico City is not the only scene of serious contemporary art in Mexico. It includes a Delftware motorcycle helmet by Agustin Solórzano; gold-glazed ceramic tacos by Luis Miguel Suro; an absorbing video showing puzzling crowd behavior by Gonzalo Lebrija; Fernando Palomar's mural-scale silhouette of a Dutch landscape painted in orange and white on the wall; and Rem Koolhass's book ''S,M,L,XL'' cut up into four different size pieces by José Dávila. JOHNSON Galleries: 57th Street SAM CADY: 'MAINE, NEW PAINTINGS,' Mary Ryan Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 397-0669, through Nov. 24. The state of Maine may have inspired more artists than any other in the Union, and here's another devoted example. In this group of canvases, closely tailored to fit the subjects, Mr. Cady celebrates the coastal village he lives in, where boats are built, fish are caught and seagulls clamor. His chef d'oeuvre, ''Morning Mirage, Jones Garden,'' depicts a long, narrow, horizontal stripe of shore eight feet long by a little over three inches wide called ''Morning Mirage, Jones Garden.'' No sky and no water are shown, but tiny islands appear at the top of the construction, giving the effect of a very distant view from a boat out in the water. Other ingenuities include cut-outs in the shape of a small dory; the hulls of a couple of boats being built, and a snow-covered dock from a walk-on perspective. But the painting is a little too slick to be all that down-homey. GLUECK WAYNE THIEBAUD, 'JUST DESSERTS,' Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331, through Dec. 18. No one did more to reanimate the tired old genre of still life painting in the last half century than did Mr. Thiebaud with his paintings of industrially regimented food products. His prints, sampled here in a 50-year retrospective, are less exciting than his paintings. Most are in black and white and on the small side. But they still convey the artist's wry vision of modern consumerism with forthright graphic efficiency, and the full-color prints of cans of paint, a row of lipsticks and a white rabbit are lovely. JOHNSON Galleries: SoHo 'THE ART OF READING,' Poets House, 72 Spring Street, (212) 431-7920, through Dec. 3. This appropriately quiet presentation of 38 small paintings, drawings, prints and photographs of people reading includes Paul Cadmus's portrait of Glenway Wescott; David Hockney's sweet colored-pencil drawing of a young man reclining on a sofa; photographs of William S. Burroughs by Allen Ginsberg; and King Babar (the elephant) reading his newspaper at the beach in a watercolor by Laurent DeBrunhoff. JOHNSON * 'RICHARD TUTTLE: IT'S A ROOM FOR 3 PEOPLE,' the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166, through Feb. 26. ''Villages'' is what Mr. Tuttle calls the five separate installations in this knotty but sparkling show of recent work. Each consists of a sculpture and two series of small drawings or paintings; no distinction is made. Each series is internally linked by a visual motif or color. The results are enchanting. They disarm aesthetic pretensions like Genius, Beauty and Greatness. They offer an adult way of seeing art and the world with a child's fresh eye. And the world according to Tuttle is a singularly rich one, minutely detailed, culturally broad, exotic and familiar, cosmopolitan and home-grown. COTTER Galleries: Chelsea SEONNA HONG: 'ANIMUS,' Oliver Kamm/5BE, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-0979, through Dec. 4. This Los Angeles-based artist won an Emmy this year for her animation work on an episode of the television cartoon series ''My Life as a Teenage Robot.'' Her first solo gallery exhibition in New York presents retro-style illustrations beautifully painted on wood panels for a yet to be published picture book about a little girl and a vicious black dog. JOHNSON RICHARD KERN/LILY VAN DER STOKKER, Feature, 530 West 25th Street, (212) 675-7772, through Dec. 11. These separate solo shows could be presented under the single title ''Innocence and Experience.'' Mr. Kern's voyeuristic, snapshot-style pictures of women -- staged using attractive models -- are uncommonly visceral instances of the so-called male gaze. Ms. van der Stokker's aggressively charming pastel-colored wall paintings of abstract blobs, cartoon flowers, plaid patterns and quirky texts project a childlike sweetness, wholesome family values and mischievous ironies. JOHNSON NICKY NODJOUMI: 'PRIVATE AGENDA,' Mike Weiss, 520 West 24th Street, (212) 691-6899, through Nov. 24. Born in Iran in 1942, Mr. Nodjoumi moved to New York in the 80's to escape censorship by the new fundamentalist government. With a skillful painterly touch and in muted colors he creates darkly humorous, poetically haunting political allegories like the image of the United States president and vice president with heads bowed in prayer carrying on their backs, respectively, a giant heart and a bundle of dried shrubbery. JOHNSON 'THE PRESIDENCY,' Exit Art, 475 10th Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 966-7745, through Nov. 21. Among the few interesting pieces in this weak selection of politically tendentious works by 41 artists are Arbuzo Virtmanis's corrugated cardboard reconstruction of the president's bedroom on Air Force One; a deadpan video cartoon by Packard Jennings in which President Bush and members of his cabinet say things they would say if they were being completely honest; and an audio piece by 31 Down Radio Theater in which the President humbly apologizes for things he has done, from running for president to invading Iraq. JOHNSON Other Galleries SITE, Senior & Shopmaker, 21 East 26th Street, (212) 213-6767, through Dec. 4. A cool new addition to Madison Square Park is the ''Shake Shack,'' a fast-food kiosk designed by the architecture firm Sculpture in the Environment (SITE) that was founded in 1970 by James Wines. It is partly a Postmodern hot dog stand, partly green architecture with its vegetation-covered roof and partly a way to generate revenue for the park. The small show of models and drawings at Senior & Shopmaker gives some background on Mr. Wines's inventive and admirable effort to integrate form, function and environment. JOHNSON 'ELECTRIFYING ART: ATSUKO TANAKA, 1954-1968,' Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780, through Dec. 11. In the late 1950's and early 1960's, Ms. Tanaka was a member of the avant-garde Japanese art group called Gutai, and the Grey Gallery survey covers the years of that association. It's a visually low-key show, but one with lots of ideas from an artist who was doing proto-Conceptualist and proto-Minimalist work and very early versions of sound and performance art. Spend time with the short films in the galleries; they bring everything else to life. COTTER ARCHIE RAND: 'THE 19 DIASPORA PAINTINGS,' Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion Museum, 1 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 824-2205, through Jan. 12. The mercurial Mr. Rand has created a series of canvases representing the Biblical history of Israel using imagery copied in a loose, colorful style from various sorts of adventure comic books. Each is captioned by Hebrew words of a traditional prayer. The paintings are unconvincing visually, but the effort to wed traditional religion and Postmodernist art is interesting. JOHNSON Last Chance 'ADAPTIVE BEHAVIOR,' New Museum of Contemporary Art/Chelsea, 556 West 22nd Street, (212) 219-1222, through tomorrow. Occupying new temporary quarters on the Chelsea Art Museum's ground floor, the New Museum presents a mostly video group show that reflects the problems of adapting to the constant changes of modern experience. Robert Melee's home-entertainment center documents his adaptation to his eccentric mother; a video by Bojan Sarcevic shows a Turkish Gypsy band learning to play Western pop songs; and, best of all, a video by Kerry Tribe shows a wonderfully charismatic 10-year-old girl thoughtfully responding to philosophical questions posed by a man off camera. Hours: Tomorrow and Saturday, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; students and 65+, $3. JOHNSON GORDON COSTER, Keith de Lellis, 47 East 68th Street, (212) 327-1482, through today. This retrospective exhibition of more than 60 photographs dating from 1925 to 1950 documents the career of a versatile and skillful photojournalist. It includes semi-abstract still-lifes and nudes, documentary pictures of inner-city life and labor and civil rights strife and pictures of idyllic family scenes made for magazine ads that are, in some ways, among the show's most provocative images. JOHNSON * FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION NATIONAL MONUMENT, Foley Square, Lower Manhattan, (212) 206-6674, through tomorrow. On a return engagement sponsored by Creative Time and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, this interactive outdoor sculpture, made in the symbolic year 1984, consists of a big, bright red Constructivist-style megaphone, through which members of the public can exercise their right to free speech. The work is a collaboration among the architect Laurie Hawkinson, the artist Erika Rothenberg and the performer John Malpede. It points, perhaps appropriately, toward the state and federal courthouses. SMITH DONALD JUDD/ROBERT MANGOLD, PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-7000, through tomorrow. The pairing of the paintings and sculptures of these major Minimalist artists is a no-brainer, especially since both are represented by this gallery. But it looks surprisingly fresh and is beautifully installed. Each artist works with simple volumes of space, whether actual or illusionistic, that are divided and measured with the addition of repeating related elements. In Mr. Mangold's work two or three lines undulate or curve from top to across the lightly gridded monochrome color-fields of his tall ''Column'' paintings. The divisions of Mr. Judd's boxed or columnar volumes of space proceed with perpendicular planes or repeating, sometimes sub-divided units. SMITH JEFF LADOUCEUR: 'SCHMO,' ZieherSmith, 531 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 229-1088, through tomorrow. With a finely pointed pen in black ink and a meticulous touch, this Vancouver-based artist draws cartoons about a bald, long-nosed, sad sack of a character called ''Schmo.'' Our hero's struggles with ordinary existence and surrealistic encounters with cloud-creatures, tiny elephants, octopuses and an abominable snowman are funny, weird and touching. JOHNSON KURT LIGHTNER: 'A VIEW ALMOST PICTURESQUE,' Clementine, 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 243-5937, through tomorrow. A single huge and enthralling landscape occupies Clementine's main gallery. Measuring 12 by 22 feet, it presents a life-size, magically vivid squirrel's eye view into a forest. Part Pre-Raphaelite, part Charles Burchfield and part Walt Disney, it was made by gluing thousands of individual images of plants, trees, stones and ferns -- each painted in acrylic ink on Mylar -- onto big paper panels. JOHNSON TOMOKO SAWADA: 'COSTUME,' Zabriskie Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-1224, through tomorrow. In the tradition of Claude Cahun, Ana Mendieta and Cindy Sherman, the Japanese artist Tomoko Sawada puts female identity through its paces, but without limiting her role-playing to the studio. She enters the real world, to pose as a dentist, policewoman, secretary, nun or tea-house hostess in what might be called their natural habitats. What's most interesting is the way Ms. Sawada adjusts her facial expression and body language to each persona and, moreover, to our preconceptions about the women's social status and psychological profile. The images need one another to be most effective, but in nearly every case, Ms. Sawada's performance is more than skin-deep, which is why it unsettles. SMITH DONALD SULTAN: 'NEW POPPY PAINTINGS,' Ameringer Yohe, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 445-0051, through tomorrow. Mr. Sultan builds his massive pictures of flat, brightly colored poppy blossoms on velvety black fields out of industrial strength materials: plywood, Masonite, linoleum, tar and enamel paint. Far from heavy-handed or over-bearing, however, his works exude a suave and seductive blend of visual and tactile sensuousness. JOHNSON VICTOR VASARELY: 'BLACK AND WHITE PAINTINGS FROM THE 1950'S,' Robert Miller, 524 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 366-4774, through tomorrow. This small but surprisingly interesting sideshow presents just six black-and-white paintings dating from 1952 to 1962. This Hungarian-born painter, who lived from 1906 to 1997, came to be thought of as a visual cheap trickster, but the optically tantalizing compositions of stripes, grid patterns and patterns like bar codes on view here have a fine, concentrated rigor. JOHNSON

docs.lead_paragraph: ON all her official papers, she is known as Joênia Batista de Carvalho. But that is not the real name of the first Indian woman to become a lawyer in Brazil, just a name a clerk randomly selected when her parents were first brought from their Amazon village to have their births registered. Whether her preoccupation with issues of cultural identity and autonomy stems from that incident, Ms. Batista is not sure. Still, when she went to the United States earlier this year to receive a Reebok Prize for her human rights work, she chose to accept the award as Joênia Wapixana, using the name of the tribe to which she belongs.

headline.main: Using Courts in Brazil to Strengthen an Indian Identity

docs.abstract: Joenia Batista de Carvalho, first Indian woman to become lawyer in Brazil, has emerged as one of most effective advocates of indigenous cause in Brazil; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Known as Joênia Batista de Carvalho, Brazil's first Indian woman to become a lawyer has emerged as one of the most effective advocates of the indigenous cause.

docs.lead_paragraph: BURIED treasure, sparkling jewels, flying dogs and fairies were all part of the fantasy. It was like a child's dream -- to create a fanciful fairy tale with elaborate drawings and hidden clues, and then invite everyone to look for gold coins hidden all over the country. It was a dream Michael Stadther had harbored for decades until he decided recently to make it come true. He wrote and illustrated a 100-page book in which the clues to the treasures are hidden in its drawings and whimsical text. Once a reader uncovers the clues, he said, the obfuscated locations will become clear. He has hidden 12 18-karat gold coins, which can be redeemed for jewels, in public areas across the United States.

headline.main: Case of Finders Keepers

docs.abstract: Article on book, A Treasure's Trove, and its author and illustrator, Michael Stadther of Pound Ridge, NY; Stadther, 50, retired software engineer, is publishing book himself and starting what he hopes will become national treasure hunt; book offers clues hidden in its drawings and whimsical text for finding 12 18-karat gold coins, which can be redeemed for jewels, in public places across US; photos (M)
docs.snippet: BURIED treasure, sparkling jewels, flying dogs and fairies were all part of the fantasy. It was like a child's dream -- to create a fanciful fairy tale with elaborate drawings and hidden clues, and then invite everyone to look for gold coins hidden...

docs.lead_paragraph: I. Get Me Gene Hackman For the past few years, Hollywood's weekend box-office tallies have come to represent a tidy bit of wisdom about American culture -- cold, bare numbers relayed around the world every Monday morning that tell us which stories and which celebrities are resonating with the moviegoing public. There is, however, another set of Hollywood statistics of enormous significance, and Tuesday is their day. How important are these numbers? Every Tuesday at lunchtime, Mike Dunn and Peter Staddon, the president and executive vice president, respectively, of 20th Century Fox's home-entertainment division, take the elevator from ther 25th-floor offices at Fox Plaza in Los Angeles down to their cars in the underground parking garage and from there drive out into the noontime traffic on their way to Best Buy, Target, Costco and Wal-Mart. Tuesday is the day new DVD's are released, the day Dunn gets a sense of whether the discs that his team has worked on for months -- or sometimes years -- will sell as well as planned. So the Fox executives wander the aisles of the big retailers. They eavesdrop. They size up the clientele. They take note of what's moving through the cash registers. Tuesday, not Monday, is their day of reckoning. And in many ways, the same is true for their parent company as well. From about 2002 on, the larger stakes in Hollywood -- the revenue that enables studios to finance blockbusters and to pay Brad Pitt and to keep the lights on -- have come to ride mostly on those little silver discs that go on sale four or five months after a theatrical release. This year, for instance, 63 percent of studio feature-film revenues in the United States will come from movies sold to retail stores; actual box office will generate only 21 percent. According to Tom Adams, a well-regarded home-entertainment analyst whose firm, Adams Media Research, tracks DVD sales and trends, studios often get twice as much revenue from a big film's retail sales as they do from its theatrical release.

headline.main: Box Office in a Box

docs.abstract: Jon Gertner article on impact of DVD's on film industry; according to Adams Media Research, studios often get twice as much revenue from big film's retail sales as they do from its theatrical release; box office successes and laggards both prove lucrative on DVD and studios are mining archives for oldies that bring in windfalls; notion that DVD has impact on content of films discussed; photos (L)
docs.snippet: How DVD's are changing everything about Hollywood.

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you examine the furnishings in J. M. Barrie's office in the movie ''Finding Neverland,'' you might notice that it is a little too austere for the Victorian era. This small liberty occurred partly because the office is meant to reflect the man who works in it: a wealthy Scottish author in a chilly, childless marriage, who keeps himself apart from most relationships. But it also reflects the taste of the Swiss director Marc Forster, who did extensive research on period decoration. ''Of course, there's a difference between when I create a set for someone in a film and when I create my home, but in both I like to have very clean lines,'' he said one afternoon at his loft here. The film, which stars Johnny Depp as Barrie and Kate Winslet as Sylvia Llewelyn Davies, is about the Llewelyn Davies family -- a mother and four boys -- who inspired ''Peter Pan.''

headline.main: Far, Far From Neverland, A Spare and Quiet Place

docs.abstract: At Home With interview with Swiss director Marc Forster on his restrained Victorian interiors for movie Finding Neverland, about J M Barrie and family that inspired Peter Pan; Forster also favors understatement in his own split-level loft in Venice, Calif; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The director of "Finding Neverland," Marc Forster, did extensive research on period decoration. Just as he displays restraint on the film, he shows understatement in his home.

docs.lead_paragraph: The expected arrival here on Friday of President Bush, who personifies for Latin Americans the economic and political power of Washington, is being greeted with an uneasy mix of protests and hopes for greater growth. But while the United States may still regard the region as its backyard, its dominance is no longer unquestioned. Suddenly, the presence of China can be felt everywhere, from the backwaters of the Amazon to mining camps in the Andes.

headline.main: China Widens Economic Role in Latin America

docs.abstract: US still regards Latin America as its backyard, but its dominance is no longer unquestioned; presence of China can be felt everywhere; China, driven by one of most sustained economic expansions and facing shortages in Asia, is increasingly turning to Latin America as supplier; Pres Hu Jintao has announced over $30 billion in new investments in region and signed long-term contracts that will guarantee China supplies of vital materials it needs for its factories; US seems to have attached little importance on China's rising profile in region; has welcomed increased trade between Latin America and China as means to reduce pressure on it to underwrite economic reforms; graph; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Driven by one of the largest and most sustained economic expansions in history, China is increasingly turning to South America as a supplier.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater. Theater Broadway + 'BROOKLYN THE MUSICAL' The enterprising design team of Mark Schoenfeld and Barri McPherson's aggressively maudlin show has come up with all sorts of ideas for converting everyday urban detritus into glamorous props and accessories, from traffic cones into megaphones to garbage bags into evening gowns. But the whole production is a kind of cultural recycling of discarded showbiz forms. An urban fairy tale told by street singers, ''Brooklyn'' is a throwback to the simple and whimsy-laden little musicals that blossomed Off Broadway several decades ago. Try to imagine a sanitized ''Hair'' or a secular ''Godspell,'' with a helping of funky 70's disco, all filtered through the vocal pyrotechnics of ''American Idol.'' If that hybrid appeals to you, you're welcome to it. If not, you may find yourself feeling like a cranky commuter in a subway car, trapped with a perky team of harmonizers who say they just want to leave you with a smile on your face (1:45). Plymouth, 236 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays at 7 p.m.; Wednesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $95. BEN BRANTLEY + 'THE GOOD BODY' In her tremendously popular ''Vagina Monologues,'' Eve Ensler exposed the connections between taboos about the discussion of female sexuality and women's oppression. Ms. Ensler has now moved on -- to her belly button. As she relates in ''The Good Body,'' ''I said the word vagina vagina vagina a million times. I thought I was home free. I had finally come to like my vagina. Until one day I realized the self-hatred had just crept up into my stomach.'' Like ''Vagina Monologues,'' ''The Good Body'' aims to uplift and to empower as it entertains. Ms. Ensler wants to soften the ever-fraught relationship between American women and their bodies.
